facts: The Sun contains more than 99% of all the mass in the Solar System, so its gravity holds everything together.
Mercury has almost no atmosphere to trap heat, which is why its days can be extremely hot and its nights can be freezing cold.
Venus spins so slowly that one Venus day is longer than one Venus year, meaning it takes longer to rotate once than to orbit the Sun.
Earth is the only known planet with liquid water on its surface, which is one key reason it can support life.
Mars has the largest volcano in the Solar System, Olympus Mons, which is about three times taller than Mount Everest.
Jupiter is so large that more than 1,300 Earths could fit inside it, and it has dozens of moons.
The Kuiper Belt is a region beyond Neptune filled with icy objects, including dwarf planets like Pluto.
sources_hint: For verification, check NASA Solar System Exploration pages and ESA educational resources on planets and small bodies.
